A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: A natural number is odd iff it has residue `1` or `3` mod `4`

For any natural numbers n and even a, n is odd if and only if the remainder of n divided by a is odd.

type: ∀ {n a : ℕ}, Even a → (Odd (n % a) ↔ Odd n)
name: Odd.mod_even_iff
docString: For any natural numbers n and even a, n is odd if and only if the remainder of n divided by a is odd.

This theorem states that a natural number is odd if and only if its remainder when divided by 4 is either 1 or 3. In other words, it characterizes odd numbers in terms of their residues modulo 4.

name: Nat.odd_mod_four_iff
docString: This theorem states that a natural number is odd if and only if its remainder when divided by 4 is either 1 or 3. In other words, it characterizes odd numbers in terms of their residues modulo 4.

Greatest common divisor of a finite set

type:
{α : Type u_1} →
  {β : Type u_2} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [inst : NormalizedGCDMonoid α] → Finset β → (β → α) → α
name: Finset.gcd
docString: Greatest common divisor of a finite set

For any prime number `p` and integer `x`, there exist natural numbers `a` and `b` with `a, b ≤ p / 2` such that `a² +b² ≡ x (mod p)`.

type: ∀ (p : ℕ) [inst : Fact p.Prime] (x : ℤ), ∃ a b, a ≤ p / 2 ∧ b ≤ p / 2 ∧ (↑p).ModEq (↑a ^ 2 + ↑b ^ 2) x
name: Nat.sq_add_sq_zmodEq
docString: For any prime number `p` and integer `x`, there exist natural numbers `a` and `b` with `a, b ≤ p / 2` such that `a² +b² ≡ x (mod p)`.

This theorem states that for all natural numbers `x` and `y`, if `y` is greater than zero, then the modulus of `x` with respect to `y` (represented as `x % y`) is less than `y`. In mathematical terms, for any positive natural number `y`, the remainder of division of any natural number `x` by `y` is always less than `y`.

name: Nat.mod_lt
docString: This theorem states that for all natural numbers `x` and `y`, if `y` is greater than zero, then the modulus of `x` with respect to `y` (represented as `x % y`) is less than `y`. In mathematical terms, for any positive natural number `y`, the remainder of division of any natural number `x` by `y` is always less than `y`.

**Lifting the exponent lemma** for odd primes.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ},
  Nat.Prime p →
    Odd p →
      ∀ {x y : ℤ},
        ↑p ∣ x - y →
          ¬↑p ∣ x → ∀ (n : ℕ), multiplicity (↑p) (x ^ n - y ^ n) = multiplicity (↑p) (x - y) + multiplicity p n
name: multiplicity.Int.pow_sub_pow
docString: **Lifting the exponent lemma** for odd primes.

No zero divisors.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [self : CanonicallyOrderedCommSemiring α] {a b : α}, a * b = 0 → a = 0 ∨ b = 0
name: CanonicallyOrderedCommSemiring.eq_zero_or_eq_zero_of_mul_eq_zero
docString: No zero divisors.

To prove Fermat's Last Theorem, it suffices to prove it for odd prime exponents.

type: (∀ (p : ℕ), Nat.Prime p → Odd p → FermatLastTheoremFor p) → FermatLastTheorem
name: FermatLastTheorem.of_odd_primes
docString: To prove Fermat's Last Theorem, it suffices to prove it for odd prime exponents.

If a small natural number is divisible by a larger natural number,
the small number is zero.

type: ∀ {a b : ℕ}, a ∣ b → b < a → b = 0
name: Nat.eq_zero_of_dvd_of_lt
docString:
If a small natural number is divisible by a larger natural number,
the small number is zero.

The GCD is a divisor of the first element.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [self : GCDMonoid α] (a b : α), gcd a b ∣ a
name: GCDMonoid.gcd_dvd_left
docString: The GCD is a divisor of the first element.

The greatest common divisor between two elements.

type: {α : Type u_2} → [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] → [self : GCDMonoid α] → α → α → α
name: GCDMonoid.gcd
docString: The greatest common divisor between two elements.

If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, 1 < Pell.Solution₁.x a → 0 < d
name: Pell.Solution₁.d_pos_of_one_lt_x
docString: If a solution has `x > 1`, then `d` is positive.

Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : IsDedekindDomain R]
  (v : IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum R) (x : ↥(nonZeroDivisors R)),
  0 < IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.intValuationDef v ↑x
name: IsDedekindDomain.HeightOneSpectrum.int_valuation_zero_le
docString: Nonzero divisors have valuation greater than zero.

`-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} [inst : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], p ≠ 2 → (IsSquare (-2) ↔ p % 8 = 1 ∨ p % 8 = 3)
name: ZMod.exists_sq_eq_neg_two_iff
docString: `-2` is a square modulo an odd prime `p` iff `p` is congruent to `1` or `3` mod `8`.

The proposition that a sequence indexed by integers is a divisibility sequence.

type: {R : Type u} → [inst : CommRing R] → (ℤ → R) → Prop
name: IsDivSequence
docString: The proposition that a sequence indexed by integers is a divisibility sequence.

If `d` is a positive integer that is not a square, then there exists a nontrivial solution
to the Pell equation `x^2 - d*y^2 = 1`.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ}, 0 < d → ¬IsSquare d → ∃ a, a ≠ 1 ∧ a ≠ -1
name: Pell.Solution₁.exists_nontrivial_of_not_isSquare
docString:
If `d` is a positive integer that is not a square, then there exists a nontrivial solution
to the Pell equation `x^2 - d*y^2 = 1`.

The discriminant `Δ'` of an elliptic curve over `R`, which is given as a unit in `R`.

type: {R : Type u} → [inst : CommRing R] → EllipticCurve R → Rˣ
name: EllipticCurve.Δ'
docString: The discriminant `Δ'` of an elliptic curve over `R`, which is given as a unit in `R`.

Any common divisor of both elements is a divisor of the GCD.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_2} [inst : CancelCommMonoidWithZero α] [self : GCDMonoid α] {a b c : α}, a ∣ c → a ∣ b → a ∣ gcd c b
name: GCDMonoid.dvd_gcd
docString: Any common divisor of both elements is a divisor of the GCD.

The finset of those partitions in which every part is odd.

type: (n : ℕ) → Finset (Nat.Partition n)
name: Nat.Partition.odds
docString: The finset of those partitions in which every part is odd.

Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

type: Set.InjOn Nat.factorization {x | x ≠ 0}
name: Nat.factorization_inj
docString: Every nonzero natural number has a unique prime factorization

If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

type: ∀ {a b : ℤ}, a ∣ b → Int.natAbs b < Int.natAbs a → b = 0
name: Int.eq_zero_of_dvd_of_natAbs_lt_natAbs
docString:
If an integer with larger absolute value divides an integer, it is
zero.

The greatest common divisor (gcd) of two positive natural numbers,
viewed as positive natural number.

name: PNat.gcd
docString:
The greatest common divisor (gcd) of two positive natural numbers,
viewed as positive natural number.

We can assume that a minimal solution to `a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 = c ^ 2` has `a` odd.

type: ∀ {a b c : ℤ}, Fermat42 a b c → ∃ a0 b0 c0, Fermat42.Minimal a0 b0 c0 ∧ a0 % 2 = 1
name: Fermat42.exists_odd_minimal
docString: We can assume that a minimal solution to `a ^ 4 + b ^ 4 = c ^ 2` has `a` odd.
